awd_titl_txt: Understanding Thermal Transport in "Breathing" Porous Crystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Porous materials are used widely in modern society, from air and water filters, to battery electrodes and catalysts for manufacturing chemicals. One particular application of porous materials is to better store gases; highly porous materials are able to soak up gases just like a bath sponge soaks up water. For example, porous materials can be used to store large amounts of oxygen in portable containers or to store natural gas in vehicles. The most effective materials for storing gases are the ones whose pores are of nanoscopic size, where each pore is just large enough to store a few molecules of gas. However, there have been two challenges that researchers have faced in developing better materials for gas storage: (1) gas getting stuck in the pores (referred to as 'stranded' gas), and (2) the pores getting excessively hot due to the heat that is generated when gases enter and bind to their surfaces. This project aims to shed light on both challenges by looking at the thermal properties of a special class of materials called 'breathing' porous crystals. The pores of these materials are able to open when gases enter, and close when gases leave, thus squeezing out any residual gas; not unlike how our lungs work. For this reason, breathing porous materials are very promising for revolutionizing industrial gas storage and separations. However, we currently have no understanding of how heat dissipates in pores that open and close in response to the presence of gases. By illuminating these thermal properties, this project will help facilitate the practical implementation of these promising breathing porous crystals. 

The objective of this research is to study heat transfer phenomena in flexible porous crystals. This project will systematically study a series of idealized flexible porous crystal structures to help build a fundamental understanding of the factors that play a role in their thermal transport properties. The guiding hypothesis is that the ratio of thermal conductivity for expanded versus contracted pores can be as much as an order of magnitude. Under vacuum conditions, the high ratio might be considered an obvious outcome based on the relative difference in crystal densities, but in the presence of gas, which would be the relevant application condition, there are corresponding changes in gas density that could counteract thermal conductivity changes. In addition to answering these questions directly, our modeling efforts will uncover structure-property relationships that could add further insight into thermal transport behavior in porous systems. Working with experimental collaborators, there will be an effort to subsequently validate the modeling results with empirical measurements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Materials with many tiny pores, so small that they can only fit a few small molecules of gas, are able to soak up gases just like a bath sponge soaks up water. Of particular interest to the scientific community in the last twenty years has been a class of porous crytals called metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). MOFs have extremely high surface areas, some more than 7000 m^2/g (like the area of a football field wrapped up into a sugar cube), and their surfaces can also be made to only bind to specific chemicals - making them useful for separating gases, as well as storing them. Such applications include CO2 capture, hydrogen storage, protective layers in gas masks, and even in water harvesting in dry desert environments.

However, MOFs have yet to find widespread industrial use because a large number of engineering challenges are yet to be resolved. Chief among those is lower the manufacturing costs, something that has attracted a lof interest particularly in recent years. Another importan factor, however, has received very little attention: thermal transport properties of MOFs. When gases enter into MOFs and bind to their inner surfaces, heat is released. When that process occurs quickly (as one would expect in an industrial process), the amount of heat is significant and the temperature of the MOF and surrounding materials can rise to levels that impede their functionality. 

Hence, it is important for MOFs to not only have high surface areas and low cost of manufacture, but they must also be able to dissipate the sometimes significant heat generated during the gas adsorption process. This NSF funded research sought to better understand how thermal transport in MOFs is affected by their structural properties and operating conditions (e.g., size of pores, degree of pore flexiblity, temperature, pressure, and the presence of gases). From the studies we performed, we obtained many useful structure-property insights. Most counter-intuitively, we found that the presence of gases at sufficiently high pressure may make MOFs more insulating, which excarbates the thermal dissipation issue. In future research, we hope these thermal transport properties are further improved and that MOFs become a viable and ubiquitous material in future technologies.

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2021
Modified by: Christopher E Wilmer

Image
  • This research studied heat transfer in a class of novel porous crystals called metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). These crystals can capture gases and separate chemicals, but sometimes significant heat is released in the process.
    Christopher Eli Wilmer
    Public Domain
    Christopher E Wilmer
    Thermal transport through a porous crystal
